Talks on Mideast Resume After Brush With Failure With President Clinton's departure for Japan, the energy drained from the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks as the delegations, trying to recover from the roller-coaster drama of late Wednesday night, slept late and then worked with the American peace team to determine how to move beyond the impasse and the mutual accusations of bad faith.

Israel's apparent willingness to give up some control of East Jerusalem has roused fears among the Arab residents there of a compromise that would fall short of Palestinian aspirations for full sovereignty, while putting at risk jobs, social services and unimpeded travel access.

Clinton Arrives in Japan President Clinton jumped from one delicate diplomatic matter to fresh ones as he arrived for an economic meeting of world leaders and immediately tried to make amends to Okinawans fed up with the heavy American military presence.

African Leaders Fault Rich Leaders of South Africa, Nigeria and Algeria held a news conference in Tokyo on the eve of a meeting of the world's leading economic powers, saying those countries had been too slow to act on debt relief and other issues vital to economic growth in the third world.
New Parliament in Zimbabwe The Parliament officially opened with the governing party forced to share space and power with a formidable opposition for the first time in more than a decade.

Holbrooke Issues a Warning Richard C. Holbrooke, taking aim at both Congress and the Clinton administration, said American reluctance to pay for United Nations peacekeeping could cost the nation much more down the line in emergency relief and the direct involvement of American troops in foreign conflicts.

Protests in Beijing Dozens of Falun Gong followers have been taken into custody in Beijing in recent days as protests increase to mark the first anniversary of the Chinese government's crackdown on the movement.

Polls and Interviews Show A Close Presidential Race The presidential election stands as a very competitive contest, despite the confidence displayed by Gov. George W. Bush's campaign, with ample time and opportunity for either him or Vice President Al Gore to surge ahead, according to an analysis of opinion polls state by state, along with interviews with Republican and Democratic strategists.

Texans Take Exception The crucible of a presidential campaign seems to have exacerbated the gap between the view others hold of Texas and the view Texans hold of themselves. Members of the Proud of Texas Committee have written to Vice President Al Gore, pledging to defend their state against his ''misrepresentations.''

Vice President Gore tried to undercut Gov. George W. Bush's popularity, suggesting that Mr. Bush's priorities were skewed and had made Texas a backwater where big oil interests were more important than children's health.

Turnabout for McCain A Republican close to Senator John McCain said the senator would accept the Republican Party's vice-presidential nomination if Gov. George W. Bush offered it. Mr. McCain had adamantly ruled out such a move several months ago.

Republicans Revise Tax Bill Republicans have unveiled a new version of their tax cut for married couples, but as the bill passed the House, they promptly found themselves under fire for making the bill cost $44 billion more overnight.

Pollution Case Settled The Environmental Protection Agency and the Justice Department said a plywood manufacturer with 13 factories in four states had agreed to a $93.2 million settlement over air pollution violations, the largest settlement based on pollution from factories.

Panel Approves War Memorial A federal panel approved the first national World War II memorial, to be situated on the Mall in Washington. Amid an emotional debate over the memorial's design and location, Bob Dole, the former Kansas senator and a veteran, was among those who urged the panel to proceed.

Claims Against the Police Fall After Five-Year Climb The number of legal claims accusing New York City police officers of excessive force or other misconduct has dropped by 25 percent over the last year, after a five-year climb, according to city statistics.

Genetic Research Under Attack A cornfield that was damaged at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory on Long Island appears to be the latest in a series of incidents across the country in which experimental crops have been destroyed and research centers vandalized by militant environmentalists who oppose the genetic modification of plants.
Banning Alcohol at Festivals The Giuliani administration is considering banning the sale of alcohol at outdoor street parties. The plan has been met with consternation by organizers of the festivals.

Ex-Aide to Pataki Questioned A former top aide to Gov. George E. Pataki came under vigorous cross-examination in a trial centering on charges that a Pataki fund-raiser solicited donations in exchange for political favors.

Rifts Over Genetic Testing Those who choose to learn their genetic risks, and the health professionals who treat them, are facing difficult decisions about how -- and whether -- to share the results with family members.
Elusive Neutrino Detected What many physicists consider to be one of the last pieces of the theoretical puzzle that explains the structure of matter has been detected.

'Footstool' of Intelligence Researchers have found that a surprisingly small and specific region of gray matter may be the brain's master problem solver, addressing a longstanding debate among scientists over how much of the brain is activated to perform a difficult task like taking an I.Q. test.
Contenders for Emmy Awards ''The Sopranos'' and ''The West Wing'' each received 18 Emmy Award nominations.

Fed May Raise Rates Again Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said there was not yet enough evidence to conclude that the economy had slowed to a noninflationary pace, and he left the door open to further interest rate increases as soon as next month.
Investors sent stock and bond prices sharply higher and interest rates lower. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 3.2 percent, and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.4 percent.

Lucent Sees Financial Dip Lucent Technologies said its financial results would fall short of expectations for the next two quarters, at least in part because the company had been caught off guard by slower demand for traditional communications systems.
Warnaco's Earnings Fall Short Warnaco Group, the maker of intimate apparel, said it would once again miss earnings estimates.
Industries Sue Arts Web Site The motion picture and music industries sued to shut down Scour.com, contending that it had permitted free trading of copyrighted music and movies.
Allen E. Paulson A pilot and airline executive who set speed records, he was 78.
